bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of part of article: Spanish Immigrants Inoculated with Yellow Fever by Means of Mosquitos, November 21, 1900

div1.p: This is a translation of an article, originally appearing in “La Discusion” (November 21, 1900 - page 2a), in which the rumor of human experimentation is discussed and criticized.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of part of article: Spanish Immigrants Inoculated with Yellow Fever by Means of Mosquitos, November 21, 1900 (See Spanish original.)
div1.opener:
{From: “La Discusion”, Wednesday,} {Nov. 21, 1900.}
! “H O R R I B L E ............I F T R U E” !
div1.p: “Spanish Immigrants Inoculated With Yellow Fever by Means of Mosquitos”
! “LET THE AUTHORITIES BE ON THEIR GUARD” !

A rumor has reached us of a happening so horrible, so repulsive
and so monstruous that resisting to believe in its existence and almost
daring to deny it, we do not hesitate to publish it -- solely as a
rumor -- in our columns, because in this way the popular version will
reach directly and rapidly the authorities, and they, if as we expect,
the happening results false, they will dissipate the alarm, and if --
which we do not believe -- it should be true, they will impose upon
its authors an exemplary punishment in accord with the importance of
the monstruous magnitude of the crime.
Here is what is being said:

As is known, the current of Spanish immigration to this Island
has for some time augmented in an extraordinary manner.. The majority
of those immigrants, as is natural, are not immune to yellow fever.

To those who remain for a short time in Triscornia (Quarantine
Station) is offered work in an American Camp in Quemados, promising
them one dollar a day, being taken in “partys” of 30 or 40 men.
And here begins the horrible part of the narrative.

At night, when the immigrants have finished their tasks, they are
shut up in special habitations in which are released a large number of
mosquitos which have bitten individuals suffering from yellow fever.
The object of this is to study practically if the contagion is due or
may be due to the inoculation from those bites. If the workman is taken
sick and dies the experiment has demonstrated its effectiveness; if the
contrary, it completely dissipates this dread.
Such is, referred to as briefly as possible, the narrative.

If, unfortunately, its existence should be proved, it would be the
most monstruous case of humanitarian ...... savagery which we have
been witness to. To make experiments in anima vili on human bodies
and of persons, although humble, honest, laborious and good, who arrive
in a country to seek riches, comfort and work, believing they will find
all the guarantees of civilized life and free countries, would be unheard
